video:video.video:title: Lifestyles of Beluga Whales
video:video.video:description: Learn more about the fascinating abilities and social structure of the Beluga whale.

video:video.video:title: Lives of Cheetahs
video:video.video:description: Wanna race? The cheetah is the world's fastest land animal; we're talking zero to 45 mph (72.4 kph) in 2.5 seconds!

video:video.video:title: Lobster Locomotion
video:video.video:description: These lobsters seem to know there's power in numbers as they link together and head for deeper waters.

video:video.video:title: World's Deadliest: Anaconda Devours World's Largest Rodent
video:video.video:description: The green anaconda can grow up to 20 feet long and weigh a whopping 200 pounds. That's a big body to feed. And the world's largest rodent, the capybara, is the perfect entree.

video:video.video:title: World's Deadliest: Super-Hearing Helps Owl Hunt
video:video.video:description: No prey in sight? No problem. With its super-powered hearing, the great grey owl can hunt rodents scurrying beneath a layer of snow two feet deep.

video:video.video:title: Guttersnipe
video:video.video:description: Bhi Bhiman's music video for his song "Guttersnipe" uses footage from the travel blog Nomadic Samuel. He was born to Sri Lankan emigrants, raised in St. Louis, based in San Francisco and has been labeled a Sri Lankan Woody Guthrie but with a much more soulful voice ala Bill Withers. His debut solo album BHIMAN is out January 24th.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: People, Plants, and Pollinators
video:video.video:description: Emerging Explorer Dino Martins says that from long-tongued bees to hawk moths, pollinators are the hidden workers that keep the planet running.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: NG Live Interview: Carol Beckwith & Angela Fisher
video:video.video:description: A clever feast spares the lives of photographers Carol Beckwith and Angela Fisher during a harrowing trip to Surmaland near the Ethiopian-Sudanese border.

video:video.video:title: In the Thick of Lion Territory
video:video.video:description: Filmmakers Dereck and Beverly Joubert spend their lives up close and personal with lions - and capture many kills on film.

video:video.video:title: Photo Camp Uganda
video:video.video:description: Get a sneak peak at Photo Camp Uganda 2006, where teenage refugees documented their lives using cameras and guidance from a team of National Geographic photographers.

video:video.video:title: Central Park Jazz Music — New York
video:video.video:description: 8mm style vignette of jazz in Central Park in New York City.

video:video.video:title: Volcano Lava
video:video.video:description: Get immersed in a volcanic landscape with bubbling lava, spewing eruptions, and colliding rivers of fire.

video:video.video:title: MY SHOT Minute - Stormy Weather
video:video.video:description: A selection of our favorite storm photos submitted to My Shot by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Ocean for Life-Interconnectedness
video:video.video:description: Ocean for Life students share what they learned about the theme of interconnectedness - the interconnectedness of the global ocean and diverse cultures.

video:video.video:title: 15. Last Sighting
video:video.video:description: On June 8, 1924, support climber Noel Odell sighted Mallory and Irvine through a gap in the clouds, heading for the summit. They were never seen alive again.

video:video.video:title: Solar Cooking
video:video.video:description: A stove powered by the sun is making a big difference in impoverished communities.

video:video.video:title: Great Energy Challenge
video:video.video:description: What is the Great Energy Challenge? See why energy is abundant around us, and how we have to find the best ways to harness it for use.

video:video.video:title: 125 Years of National Geographic
video:video.video:description: Featuring show-stopping imagery and thrilling behind-the-scenes tales, National Geographic 125 Years captures the heart of National Geographic's fascinating history, from its earliest days as a scientific club to its growth into one of the world's largest geographic organizations.The book reveals how much we've come to know about our fascinating world through the pages and unforgettable imagery of National Geographic, and taps key voices from the forefront of ocean and space exploration, climate science, archaeology, mountaineering, and many other disciplines to peer with us over the horizon and see where we are heading in the future. Available wherever books are sold.

video:video.video:title: The National Geographic Society: Let's Explore!
video:video.video:description: New technology is creating an exciting new age of exploration in which we are all explorers. Join us and let's explore! Click here to register and start exploring today.

video:video.video:title: Visions of Earth
video:video.video:description: Our world offers moments of inspiration and awe — and these opportunities are everywhere we look. Visions of Earth, a new book from National Geographic, raises a curtain on the wonders of the world with amazing photography and facts about our planet in a gallery of stunning landscapes, fascinating people, amazing animals, and unexpected glimpses of the usual and unusual.

video:video.video:title: National Geographic on the iPad
video:video.video:description: National Geographic has optimized its online collection for the iPad, starting with a custom-built, interactive version of the full print edition of the magazine with brilliant photography, graphics, and video. And that's just the beginning. Check it out for yourself!

video:video.video:title: The Complete National Geographic: Every Issue Since 1888 on DVD or Hard Drive
video:video.video:description: Unearth the secrets of the Egyptian pyramids. Live with species rarely seen. Rediscover how courageous explorers found the remains of the Titanic. These adventures and thousands more from National Geographic magazine's past 121 years are waiting in this incredible 6-disc boxed set. Start your expedition!

video:video.video:title: National Geographic Atlas of the World, 9th Edition
video:video.video:description: In today's fast-paced global society, the National Geographic Atlas of the World 9th Edition is your must-have tool for making sense of the world events, critical issues, natural disasters, and cultural clashes making headlines every day.

video:video.video:title: What's Your Dream Storytelling Project?
video:video.video:description: Get ready for the storytelling opportunity of a lifetime. With the Fulbright-National Geographic Digital Storytelling Fellowship you could get funding to spend nine months abroad, working to bring the major social and environmental issues of our time to a global digital audience—all with the help of National Geographic’s editorial staff and expenses provided by the U.S. Department of State’s Fulbright Program. We want to know about your dream project covering a global issue that speaks to your curiosity and passion.What's next? You tell us.Competition deadline: February 28, 2014 5 p.m. EST.

video:video.video:title: My Wonderful World 60-second PSA
video:video.video:description: Help kids understand their world today, so they can succeed in it tomorrow.

video:video.video:title: Eden at the End of the World
video:video.video:description: Journey to the wilds of Patagonia with this trailer for the National Geographic special Eden at the End of the World, on PBS (check local listings).

video:video.video:title: Water: State of the Earth
video:video.video:description: In 2006, higher levels of carbon dioxide in the air had a negative impact on oceans, hitting marine life hard.

video:video.video:title: Camel Racing in Niger
video:video.video:description: When National Geographic writer Donovan Webster and his son James traveled to Niger for the annual Tuareg Festival, they had a chance to witness one of the main events first hand: riding alongside the camel races in a desert jeep. It's a bumpy, dusty ride, but a perspective that's incredibly unique.

video:video.video:title: Sundance #2
video:video.video:description: All Roads makes an impact at the Sundance Film Festival.

video:video.video:title: Sundance #1
video:video.video:description: All Roads is at Sundance with the premiere of Four Sheets to the Wind, a film funded by the All Roads seed grant program.

video:video.video:title: Climate Change: State of the Earth
video:video.video:description: In 2006, Arctic sea ice shrank 6 percent more than it usually does, further speeding up global warming and threatening the survival of polar bears.

video:video.video:title: My Wonderful World 30-second PSA
video:video.video:description: Help kids understand their world today, so they can succeed in it tomorrow.

video:video.video:title: Night Runners
video:video.video:description: With nothing to do, runners take to the streets for this sport that has "no winners, only players."

video:video.video:title: La petite chasse - Hunting Small Game
video:video.video:description: Big-game hunting is a pursuit traditionally reserved for the men throughout the Innu First Nation community in the Quebec region. However, in this film, Huguette Basilish passes this tradition on to her daughter, Noemie.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Jason De León: Decoding Stories of Border Crossing
video:video.video:description: Using archaeology to study the recent past, anthropologist and National Geographic Emerging Explorer Jason De León seeks to reveal human stories and new insights into the controversial topic of illegal border crossings.The National Geographic Live! series brings thought-provoking presentations by today’s leading explorers, scientists, photographers, and performing artists right to your YouTube feed. Each presentation is filmed in front of a live audience at National Geographic headquarters in Washington, D.C. New clips air every Monday.

video:video.video:title: Delphic Oracle
video:video.video:description: Archaeologists try to uncover the truth behind a Greek prophecy.

video:video.video:title: White Squirrels
video:video.video:description: Squirrels come in many colors. But the white squirrels of Marionville, Missouri, are a puzzler. How did they get that way?

video:video.video:title: Eco Heating
video:video.video:description: Warm your home without warming the planet. Try these tips to stay comfortable while saving money.

video:video.video:title: Photo Software
video:video.video:description: Learn how your photo software tools can bring out the best in your pictures.

video:video.video:title: The Cats of Pete's Pond
video:video.video:description: This clip from Pete's Pond, Botswana, captures a rare glimpse of two big African cats resting in close proximity to each other. Both leopards and lions hunt mostly at night and use the heat of the day to recharge their batteries.

video:video.video:title: Henri Dikongué—'Ndol'asu'
video:video.video:description: Cameroonian singer and guitarist Henri Dikongué mixes elements of makossa, bikutsi, reggae and rumba, and pulls them all together with classically-inflected guitar work.

video:video.video:title: Fanfare Ciocarlia—'Manea Cu Voca'
video:video.video:description: Romanian Rom (gypsy) ensemble Fanfare Ciocarlia are part of a brass band tradition that stretches from the Balkans to the Black Sea, with origins in the janissary bands of the Ottoman armies. This video is from the 2002 film Brass on Fire.

video:video.video:title: Megalosaurus
video:video.video:description: Travel to a Jurassic Park of 150 years ago and see how paleontologists first tried to piece together the bones of a massive, meat-eating Megalosaurus.

video:video.video:title: T. Rex Bite
video:video.video:description: Go inside the studio and see the birth of a cover shot. See what National Geographic photographers had to do to capture the bone-exploding force of a T. rex bite.

video:video.video:title: MY SHOT Minute - Everyday People
video:video.video:description: A selection of our favorite people photos submitted to My Shot by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: Sharks vs. Pig Carcass: Experiments Surprise Scientists
video:video.video:description: February 26, 2010—After dropping dead pigs into the sea and watching via Webcams, researchers were "very surprised" to see marine scavengers risk low–oxygen waters for a meal.

video:video.video:title: 04/18/2009: Camp 1 Arrival
video:video.video:description: The First Team arrives at Camp 1 on the Western Cwm while Dave Hahn and the rest of the team continue Icefall training below.

video:video.video:title: 05/19/2009: Update #4
video:video.video:description: Peter Whittaker calls in a radio update from the South Summit, at 28,700 feet (8,747 meters). The team presses onward toward the Hillary Step.

video:video.video:title: Good Eats
video:video.video:description: Some food photos by National Geographic readers.

video:video.video:title: I Didn't Know That: Diamonds
video:video.video:description: Learn how diamonds do more than just shine as flashy bling.

video:video.video:title: Baboons Can Learn Words?
video:video.video:description: April 12, 2012—Baboons can master one of the basic elements of reading-telling the difference between sequences of letters that make words, a new study says.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Osvel Hinojosa Huerta: Bringing Water Back to the River
video:video.video:description: The Colorado River was once mighty enough to carve the Grand Canyon, but now human use drains it to a trickle that never reaches the sea. National Geographic Emerging Explorer Osvel Hinojosa Huerta is leading efforts to change that.

video:video.video:title: Roots of the Mali Crisis
video:video.video:description: January 19, 2013—The West African nation of Mali is making headlines after a wave of French military actions on Islamic extremist groups now controlling the northern part of the country. National Geographic Senior Writer Peter Gwin has spent months traveling throughout Mali and its neighboring countries since 2005. He explains how history and geography helped create the current crisis.

video:video.video:title: NG Live!: Børge Ousland: Breaking Records in the Arctic
video:video.video:description: World-renowned polar explorer Børge Ousland shares his harrowing and hilarious adventures exploring the North Pole by ski and circumnavigating the Arctic Ocean by sailboat.

video:video.video:title: Photographing the Grand Canyon from Space
video:video.video:description: How do you touch space without even leaving the ground? Near Space Photographer John Flaig outfits weather balloons with cameras to capture novel images of iconic landscapes, such as the Grand Canyon.
